title: U=U, 100%!
notes: U=U concept is scientifically accurate (CDC/WHO/NIH endorsed). However, post contains a significant typo: uses > (greater than) instead of < (less than) for viral load thresholds. Should read <200 and <40, not >200 and >40. This error could confuse readers about what undetectable means. Community reinforces accurate science and adds important context about trust, adherence, and other STIs. Great demo of: community correcting/contextualizing imperfect information.

title: HIV is life altering whether your on treatment or not (What they don’t tell you)
notes: Contains real science with legitimate PubMed citations (gut damage, lymphatic fibrosis). However, title/framing is alarmist and suggests treatment doesn't work well - misleading. Overstates universality of symptoms and permanent damage. Valid lived experience but missing context that MOST people on ART live relatively normal lives. Community shows mixed response - some validate experience, some question if AI-generated. Great demo of: subtle misinformation detection, community debate.

title: was recently diagnosed with hiv
notes: Personal disclosure seeking support. No health claims made. Overwhelmingly supportive community response with knowledge brokers (30+ year survivors) educating newly diagnosed person. Practical advice (keep meds by bedside), hope (cure research), and some tough love accountability. Perfect demo of: peer support patterns, community resilience, knowledge broker identification.

title: Now that prep exists folks are being fucking weird about me wanting to use condoms
notes: Discusses risk perception and PrEP vs condoms. Post has slightly preachy/morally superior tone but raises valid concerns. Reveals potential knowledge gap in community (PrEP only prevents HIV, not other STIs). Community response is highly educational: reminds about drug-resistant gonorrhea, shares STI experiences, supports bodily autonomy. Balanced perspectives (some prefer condoms, some raw with PrEP). Great demo of: community health education in action, risk decision-making discussions.
